p: The objective of this study is to evaluate the susceptibility of Campylobacter strains to various NPs and frontline antibiotics. Cinnamon extract, oil, and trans (E)-Cinnamaldehyde had the lowest anti- Campylobacter activities, ranging from 25 to 200 µg/mL, which concurs with previous results where the range was from 46.8–600 µg/mL [ 28, 44, 45]. However, the MIC for cinnamon oil was lower than the 1000 µg/mL reported against Campylobacter strains in Egypt [ 28]. Clove oil and its major compound eugenol had MICs varying from 50–100 µg/mL, which are higher than the previously reported value of 20 µg/mL for clove oil [ 33] but lower than the 500 µg/mL reported for eugenol [ 28]. Other studies have also reported the strong anti- Campylobacter potential of cinnamon and clove oil [ 45, 46]. Essential oils are given to broilers to control Campylobacter [ 46]. The difference in MIC values could be associated with the method used as some researchers used an agar-based method instead of the recommended broth microdilution [ 28]. Other probable reasons could be the location and extraction procedures [ 47] or the presence of biofilm, virulence, and antibiotic-resistance genes [ 3].
